quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 1 Session 2
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 1 Session 2
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 2) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601032
entry.itemBody: Valuation of a swap during its life will least likely involve the:

answerFeedback.1321d952-479e-4d0c-85f3-5018035bcaf2: Correct because risk neutrality, not risk aversion, is a key element of derivatives pricing, including swaps. Risk aversion is not involved in pricing swaps.
answerFeedback.9647a14f-1447-40c9-9010-b4dc4ee2ee3d: Incorrect because replication is used in pricing swaps.
answerFeedback.ed050095-a4a4-4455-8f78-71471c4db218: Incorrect because the principle of no arbitrage is applied in pricing swaps.

choices.itemBody: C. application of the principle of no arbitrage.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00083
entry.itemBody: A passive investment strategy most likely outperforms an active investment strategy when:

answerFeedback.20b913c3-bd6b-4905-ba39-c0c3d30fb1ad: Incorrect because a large number of investors (individual and institutional) follow the major financial markets closely on a daily basis, and if mispricings exist in these markets investors will act so that these mispricings disappear quickly. A low number of participants contributes to a market's inefficiency, which in turn provides an opportunity for active rather than passive investment. If investors believe a market is highly efficient, they will usually accept market prices as accurately reflecting intrinsic values.
answerFeedback.63d1add9-4c73-4ca5-9f6e-f717285f88bc: Correct because an efficient market is a market in which asset prices reflect new information quickly and rationally. In a highly efficient market, a passive investment strategy (i.e., buying and holding a broad market portfolio) that does not seek superior risk-adjusted returns is preferred to an active investment strategy because of lower costs (for example, transaction and information-seeking costs).
answerFeedback.e83c3676-2a59-48a5-9716-0ac9c648813c: Incorrect because if investors believe a market is highly efficient, they will usually accept market prices as accurately reflecting intrinsic values. Active investors seek to own assets selling below perceived intrinsic value in the marketplace and to sell or sell short assets selling above perceived intrinsic value.

choices.itemBody: C. intrinsic values are less than market values.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B FI 04DTL12U3
entry.itemBody: A bond that allows the issuer to pay interest in the form of additional amounts of the existing bond issue rather than a cash payment best describes a:

answerFeedback.1f354bb1-bf2a-4d99-94ae-4a0ab033e96d: Incorrect because a deferred coupon bond, sometimes called a split coupon bond, pays no coupons for its first few years but then pays a higher coupon than it otherwise normally would for the remainder of its life. It does not allow the issuer to pay interest in the form of additional amounts of the bond issue in lieu of a cash payment.
answerFeedback.8bfa3608-ab61-4d48-8d02-564994c0aeae: Incorrect because the coupon of a step-up coupon bond, which may be fixed or floating, increases by specified margins at specified dates. It does not allow the issuer to pay interest in the form of additional amounts of the bond issue in lieu of a cash payment.
answerFeedback.ccc93be7-3fbb-4246-9ec8-c90b9ee46e56: Correct because a payment-in-kind (PIK) coupon bond typically allows the issuer to pay interest in the form of additional amounts of the bond issue rather than as a cash payment.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Islam-23
entry.itemBody: The justified forward P/E ratio calculated based on the Gordon growth model is always positively related to the:

answerFeedback.7282ad7f-7575-49b2-b580-ab95f597fda3: Incorrect because based on the Gordon growth model, the justified forward P/E is calculated by dividing the dividend payout ratio by the difference between the required rate of return and dividend growth rate. The P/E and the payout ratio appear to be positively related. This relationship may not be true, however, because a higher payout ratio may imply a slower growth rate as a result of the company retaining a lower proportion of earnings for reinvestment.
answerFeedback.ab022132-62ac-4ed2-94ed-b1b0b4c6d056: Correct because, based on the Gordon growth model, the justified forward P/E is calculated by dividing the dividend payout ratio by the difference between the required rate of return and dividend growth rate. The P/E is inversely related to the required rate of return and positively related to the growth rate; that is, as the required rate of return increases, the P/E declines, and as the growth rate increases, the P/E increases.
answerFeedback.ff300c2f-eddf-41cb-a21f-f773109ce7c6: Incorrect because, based on the Gordon growth model, the justified forward P/E is calculated by dividing the dividend payout ratio by the difference between the required rate of return and dividend growth rate. The P/E is inversely related to the required rate of return. As the required rate of return increases, the P/E declines.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-13
entry.itemBody: With respect to leveraged buyouts, the current management team will continue to manage the company in:

answerFeedback.24dfa9b6-bbed-4096-8203-333174abe03a: Correct because the leveraged buyout may also be of a specific type. In management buyouts (MBOs), the current management team is involved in the acquisition, and in management buy-ins (MBIs), the current management team is being replaced and the acquiring team will be involved in managing the company.
answerFeedback.2de1bdf2-5b3f-4022-8fd6-fc23184d5507: Incorrect because the leveraged buyout may also be of a specific type. In management buyouts (MBOs), the current management team is involved in the acquisition, and in management buy-ins (MBIs), the current management team is being replaced and the acquiring team will be involved in managing the company.
answerFeedback.98b8757a-e3b2-4d4c-842d-c14d4c3b6a57: Incorrect because the leveraged buyout may also be of a specific type. In management buyouts (MBOs), the current management team is involved in the acquisition, and in management buy-ins (MBIs), the current management team is being replaced and the acquiring team will be involved in managing the company.

choices.itemBody: C. both management buy-ins and management buyouts.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Alt-Berlinicke-03
entry.itemBody: Electronic trading in cryptocurrencies on centralized exchanges is most likely:

answerFeedback.4239e395-64a4-4b6a-b42e-1d248a4926d7: Incorrect because trading is hosted on private servers, exposing the centralized exchanges and their clients to security vulnerabilities.
answerFeedback.44b14573-55b7-4048-aa30-fd769366ce4d: Correct because trading is electronic and direct, without any intermediating broker or dealer.
answerFeedback.9d345ecc-2490-4d64-80cd-d49e912ccd6c: Incorrect because unlike the exchanges for more traditional assets, such as equity securities and futures contracts, cryptocurrency and cryptocurrency trading venues are largely unregulated, and individuals or groups may engage in fraud or market manipulation.

choices.itemBody: B. direct without any intermediating broker or dealer.
C. regulated to the same standard as exchanges for more traditional assets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Croitoru-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following objectives of a client's IPS is best described as a relative risk objective? For the next year, a client's portfolio objective is to:

answerFeedback.19b38d98-7df8-4b7f-9edb-c0c88b11b595: Incorrect because value at risk is an absolute risk measure, not a relative one. Examples of an absolute risk objective would be a desire not to suffer any loss of capital or not to lose more than a given percentage of capital in any 12-month period. For example, the desire not to lose more than 4% of capital in any 12-month period might be restated as an objective that with 95% probability the portfolio not lose more than 4% in any 12-month period. Measures of absolute risk include the variance or standard deviation of returns and value at risk.
answerFeedback.5635ff36-8f7d-4ab4-bc52-e67a788a89df: Correct because some clients may choose to express relative risk objectives, which relate risk relative to one or more benchmarks perceived to represent appropriate risk standards. When a policy portfolio is used, the risk objective may be expressed as a desire for the portfolio return to be within a band of plus or minus X% of the benchmark return calculated by assigning an index or benchmark to represent each asset class present in the policy portfolio. Again, this objective may be more usefully interpreted as a statement of probability—for example, a 95% probability that the portfolio return will be within X% of the benchmark return over a stated period.
answerFeedback.c6704afa-c7d6-4caf-a7b5-4121c1e72893: Incorrect because it represents a relative return objective, not a relative risk objective. The return objective can be stated on a relative basis—for example, relative to a benchmark return. The benchmark could be an equity market index, such as the S&P 500 or the FTSE 100, or a cash rate of interest. A relative return objective might be stated as, for example, a desire to outperform the benchmark index by one percentage point per year.

choices.itemBody: A. have a 95% value at risk that is less than $100,000.
B. outperform the local stock market index by 100 basis points.
C. earn a return within plus or minus 2 percentage points of the local stock market index return.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FI-Hung-04
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is not a credit enhancement in asset-backed securities?

answerFeedback.0380a2e9-1e8c-49d2-9c55-8fd25ee410e1: Incorrect because overcollateralization is a form of credit enhancement in ABS structures. Credit enhancements are provisions that are used to reduce the credit risk of a bond issue. They include (1) internal credit enhancements, such as subordination, overcollateralization, and reserve accounts, and (2) external credit enhancements, such as financial guarantees by banks or insurance companies, letters of credit, and cash collateral accounts.
answerFeedback.1db9b294-15c2-4aa7-894e-fcbcb1e658d0: Incorrect because credit tranching is a form of credit enhancement in ABS structures. It is common for securitizations to include a form of internal credit enhancement called subordination, also referred to as credit tranching.
answerFeedback.c0bd3a1c-fbc9-4d8c-80ab-b73ac78e2e6a: Correct because representations and warranties are only provisions in the legal documentation of an ABS, not a credit enhancement. An important legal document is the purchase agreement between the seller of the collateral and the SPE, which sets forth the representations and warranties that the seller makes about the assets sold. These representations and warranties assure investors about the quality of the assets, an important consideration when assessing the risks associated with the ABS.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-26
entry.itemBody: A bond has an annual modified duration of 5.359, an annual convexity of 248.23, and is currently yielding 3.5%. If the bond’s yield-to-maturity increases to 3.7%, the expected percentage price change is closest to:

answerFeedback.026e9fba-bbcf-4939-80e7-5849799a6437: Correct because the expected price change is: %ΔPVFull ≈ (–AnnModDur x chg.Yield) + [1/2 x AnnConvexity x (ΔYield)2] = (–5.359 x 0.002) + [1/2 x 248.230 x (0.002)2] ≈ –0.01022 ≈ –1.02%.
answerFeedback.0f25c954-fd1d-4e6b-ac52-8362602ccdcd: Incorrect because the expected price change is: %ΔPVFull ≈ (–AnnModDur x chg.Yield) + [1/2 x AnnConvexity x (ΔYield)2]. This answer ignores the negative sign in front of the AnnModDur term: (5.359 x 0.002) + [1/2 x 248.230 x (0.002)2] = 0.01121 ≈ 1.12%.
answerFeedback.cac2aeab-5f51-43f0-8c2d-cae2bbc8b1dd: Incorrect because the expected price change is: %ΔPVFull ≈ (–AnnModDur x chg.Yield) + [1/2 x AnnConvexity x (ΔYield)2]. This answer fails to multiply the second term by 1/2: (–5.359 x 0.002) + [248.230 x (0.002)2] ≈ –0.00973 ≈ –0.97%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Fairborn-08
entry.itemBody: In limited partnership agreements, which of the following benefits the general partner? A:

answerFeedback.14f0a1fe-adbf-47d5-a09d-cd47522ba7c4: Incorrect because clawback provisions benefit limited partners by allowing them to clawback prior incentive fees. A clawback provision reflects the right of LPs to reclaim part of the GP’s performance fee if a GP ever accrues (or actually pays itself) an incentive fee on gains that are not yet fully realized and then subsequently gives back these gains, an investor is typically able to claw back prior incentive fee accruals and payments. Hence, a clawback provision benefits the investors, not the general partners.
answerFeedback.54e3ff5d-79e8-4d6a-a01b-25c18bada3f3: Correct because catch-up clauses benefit general partners. A catch-up clause allows the GP to receive 100% of the distributions above the hurdle rate until 20% (i.e., the performance fee) of the profits generated is received, and then every excess dollar is split 80/20 between the LPs and GP. By contrast, absent a catch-up clause, the entire distribution above the hurdle rate is split 80/20 between the LPs and GP, reducing the GP’s return. Hence, a catch-up clause benefits the GP.
answerFeedback.ab8658a6-d5c9-4078-869a-0edac85252cc: Incorrect because high-water marks protect the clients (i.e., limited partners) who invest with general partners. A high-water mark clause states that a hedge fund manager must recuperate declines in value from the high-water mark before performance fees can be charged on newly generated profits. The use of high-water marks protects clients from paying twice for the same performance. Hence, a high-water mark benefits the limited partners, not the general partners.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.06-Alt-Gottschalk-05
entry.itemBody: Which of the following methods of investing in alternative investments requires the least amount of investment expertise?

answerFeedback.13d8b9ff-7655-4807-b022-d51bfd25faaf: Incorrect because one of the advantages of fund investing is that it provides access to alternative investments without possessing a high degree of investment expertise, whereas direct investing requires more investment expertise and a higher level of financial sophistication compared with fund investing and co-investing.
answerFeedback.27204c80-abd4-45d3-88c0-7f93d6e1e684: Correct because one of the advantages of fund investing is that it provides access to alternative investments without possessing a high degree of investment expertise.
answerFeedback.e879075a-384b-4db9-9c89-e9c70b75fa1c: Incorrect because one of the advantages of fund investing is that it provides access to alternative investments without possessing a high degree of investment expertise. On the other hand, co-investing requires more active involvement compared with fund investing, which can be challenging if resources and due diligence experience are limited. Co-investing requires more active involvement from the investor, who must evaluate both investment opportunities and the fund manager, which demands more resources, concentration, and expertise.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04508
entry.itemBody: The first decision when constructing a security market index is most likely:

answerFeedback.523d7853-ee30-4ad4-a716-4c77a226ed68: Incorrect because identifying the investment universe for inclusion is the second step when creating an index. The target market determines the investment universe and the securities available for inclusion in the index.
answerFeedback.8a283187-6b74-4677-9636-2448d1a145d6: Correct because the first decision in index construction is identifying the target market, market segment, or asset class that the index is intended to represent.
answerFeedback.bf3c16e3-7cda-4d00-800b-1284f00da6e3: Incorrect because determining the constituent securities is the last―not first―decision to be made when creating an index. Identifying the target market is the first decision and determines the investment universe and the securities available for inclusion in the index.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Roberts-24
entry.itemBody: The assets underlying an infrastructure investment are most likely:

answerFeedback.42ab66bd-7be8-45eb-a2b2-7f0d109db34f: Incorrect because infrastructure investments are intended for public, not private use. Infrastructure investments are real, capital-intensive, and long-lived assets intended for public use and provide essential services.
answerFeedback.43a5cab6-36d8-404d-82d2-b8c34f2ea6c4: Correct because most infrastructure assets are financed, owned, and operated by governments.
answerFeedback.92f010b0-5170-4ac3-8411-c42eb0bc6f04: Incorrect because infrastructure assets are typically long-lived, as opposed to having a short operational life. Infrastructure investments are real, capital-intensive, and long-lived assets intended for public use and provide essential services.

choices.itemBody: C. expected to have a short operational life.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05709
entry.itemBody: During times of severe market turmoil, the risk reduction from portfolio diversification most likely:

answerFeedback.1816d5e7-463a-4a11-8f21-a4db52d0a0f3: Incorrect because although portfolio diversification generally does reduce risk, it does not necessarily provide the same level of risk reduction during times of severe market turmoil as it does when the economy and markets are operating ‘normally.' In fact, if the economy or markets fail totally (which has happened numerous times around the world), then diversification is a false promise.
answerFeedback.67770f71-d719-4bec-9f44-d9d47ebf43d1: Incorrect because although portfolio diversification generally does reduce risk, it does not necessarily provide the same level of risk reduction during times of severe market turmoil as it does when the economy and markets are operating ‘normally.' In fact, if the economy or markets fail totally (which has happened numerous times around the world), then diversification is a false promise.
answerFeedback.ed175c66-843d-4c5c-9c28-57663897f1eb: Correct because although portfolio diversification generally does reduce risk, it does not necessarily provide the same level of risk reduction during times of severe market turmoil as it does when the economy and markets are operating ‘normally.' In fact, if the economy or markets fail totally (which has happened numerous times around the world), then diversification is a false promise.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Equity-Tyler-15
entry.itemBody: Free-cash-flow-to-equity is equal to cash flow from operations:

answerFeedback.30c1be20-abfc-4c1d-8389-4bd3ecb13076: Correct because free-cash-flow-to-equity (FCFE) can be expressed as FCFE = CFO – FCInv + Net borrowing where CFO is cash flow from operations and FCInv is fixed capital investment.
answerFeedback.952d7eb4-7a12-4c6a-bed3-05c776b50a86: Incorrect because free-cash-flow-to-equity (FCFE) can be expressed as FCFE = CFO – FCInv (not plus FCInv) + Net borrowing (not minus net borrowing) where CFO is cash flow from operations and FCInv is fixed capital investment.
answerFeedback.eca01dbd-2153-4592-8135-6c44a4f1ea7b: Incorrect because free-cash-flow-to-equity (FCFE) can be expressed as FCFE = CFO – FCInv + Net borrowing (not minus net borrowing) where CFO is cash flow from operations and FCInv is fixed capital investment.

choices.itemBody: A. less fixed capital investment less net borrowing.
B. less fixed capital investment plus net borrowing.
C. plus fixed capital investment less net borrowing.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Mazur-07
entry.itemBody: A 5% corporate bond makes annual coupon payments on 19 March of each year. If the bond is priced for settlement on 25 March at a yield-to-maturity of 5%, its flat price is:

answerFeedback.12ebfd67-81ba-4c5c-9818-c0fe4d8945c3: Incorrect because the flat price of the bond is below par value, even though the coupon rate and the yield-to-maturity are equal, because the accrued interest does not take into account the time value of money. Note that the accrued interest portion of the full price does not depend on the yield-to-maturity. Therefore, it is only the flat price that is affected by a change in interest rates.
answerFeedback.43cfc392-b9b0-4cf3-b604-f9a80ee5e977: Incorrect because the flat price of the bond is a little below par value, even though the coupon rate and the yield-to-maturity are equal, because the accrued interest does not take into account the time value of money.
answerFeedback.54a248f5-df09-481e-b74b-1fabaa6b13e6: Correct because the flat price of the bond is below par value, even though the coupon rate and the yield-to-maturity are equal, because the accrued interest does not take into account the time value of money (and the flat price is the full price minus accrued interest). The accrued interest is the portion of the next coupon payment owed to the seller of a bond, because although the seller held the bond for a partial coupon period, the full coupon will be received by the buyer. Note that the accrued interest portion of the full price does not depend on the yield-to-maturity. Therefore, it is only the flat price that is affected by a change in interest rates.

entry.title: ITEM_20190531026
entry.itemBody: A good risk management framework:

answerFeedback.258015bf-cb93-4729-8661-8d587e4ef5f1: Incorrect. Risk governance is the top-down process and guidance that directs risk management activities to align with and support the overall enterprise.
answerFeedback.96825441-45c5-495a-bfdb-48d32c41baa7: Correct. Good risk management may not prevent losses but provides a framework that addresses common factors, such as risk governance, risk infrastructure, policies and procedures, risk monitoring, and integration, among others. A risk management framework flows logically from the definition of risk management that was previously given: It is the infrastructure, process, and analytics needed to support effective risk management in an organization. This process should fully integrate the “risk” and “return” aspects of the enterprise into decisions in support of best achieving its goals within its tolerance for risk. Risk management is not a “one-size-fits-all” solution; it is integral to the enterprise’s goals and needs. Despite customization, every risk management framework should address the common factors listed above.
answerFeedback.cd460319-1d6b-4e70-9ae9-c375e9f37e1a: Incorrect. A good risk management framework prioritizes the definition of policies and procedures over avoidance of financial loss.

choices.itemBody: A. is a top-down process and guidance directing risk management activities.
B. seeks to prioritize avoidance of financial loss over defining policies and processes.
C. is typically a process that addresses a common set of factors within different organizations.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02884
entry.itemBody: Indifference curves are plotted on a graph, with returns on the vertical axis and risk on the horizontal axis. For a risk-averse investor, the slope of the indifference curve is most likely:

answerFeedback.45f2b5cc-4ac3-49c2-8f1e-16e0c01cf9e9: Incorrect because the indifference curves of risk-neutral investors are horizontal (flat) because the utility is invariant with risk.
answerFeedback.7d6a0ec4-29dc-4ed9-8626-8dbe9cf55e84: Incorrect because the risk-loving investor's indifference curve exhibits a negative slope, implying that the risk-lover is happy to substitute risk for return.
answerFeedback.94fa37de-f14c-4349-89d0-f432a4dc15a4: Correct because the indifference curve for risk-averse investors runs from the southwest to the northeast because of the risk–return trade–off. If risk increases (going east) then it must be compensated by higher return (going north) to generate the same utility. The greater the slope, the higher is the risk aversion of the investor as a greater increment in return is required to accept a given increase in risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Lamba-06
entry.itemBody: In the binomial option model, when the volatility of the underlying increases, the value of a call option:

answerFeedback.afe1c92c-3427-4206-bdad-1b6cd5d7c895: Incorrect because if volatility increases, the difference between S1+ and S1− increases, which widens the range between c1+ and c1−, leading to a higher option value. So, the option value will increase, not decrease.
answerFeedback.c75ddc45-54b1-40cc-b7fb-ece16d30581d: Correct because if volatility increases, the difference between S1+ and S1− increases, which widens the range between c1+ and c1−, leading to a higher option value.
answerFeedback.df42a904-b699-4c92-bc67-c41a82657117: Incorrect because if volatility increases, the difference between S1+ and S1− increases, which widens the range between c1+ and c1−, leading to a higher option value. So, the option value will increase, not remain unchanged.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601018
entry.itemBody: A corporation issues 5-year fixed-rate bonds. Its treasurer expects interest rates to decline for all maturities for at least the next year. She enters into a 1-year agreement with a bank to receive quarterly fixed-rate payments and to make payments based on floating rates benchmarked on 3-month Libor. This agreement is best described as a:

answerFeedback.111a65a8-e696-44ae-8149-26bdda969523: Incorrect because the instrument described is a swap.
answerFeedback.3308c690-57ea-4fd1-9974-d1642f4a5d60: Incorrect because a forward contract includes one payment only. The swap described has a series of four quarterly payments.
answerFeedback.c5d93b76-c539-4b4e-83c1-809fb2c8ec70: Correct because a swap is an agreement between two parties to exchange a series of future cash flows. In this case, the corporation receives fixed interest rate payments and makes variable interest rate payments. Given that the contract is for one year and the floating rate is based on three-month Libor, at least four payments will be made during the year.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516061
entry.itemBody: A trader buys 500 shares of a stock on margin at $36 a share using an initial leverage ratio of 1.66. The maintenance margin requirement for the position is 30%. The stock price at which the margin call will occur is closest to:

answerFeedback.06681c3e-38ca-4eb3-8df0-11d6133a3185:
Incorrect because it calculates the initial equity per share at the time of purchase = $36 × 0.40 = $14.40 (where 0.4 is the incorrect % of initial equity).

Price at which margin call occurs:

Equity per share/Price per share = Maintenance margin %

($14.40 + P – $36)/P = 0.30

0.7P = $21.60

P = $30.86
answerFeedback.34b5cce5-abe6-44ba-8ee6-aaa66f97217a:
Correct because initial equity (%) in the margin transaction = 1/Leverage ratio = 1/1.66 = 0.60. Initial equity per share at the time of purchase = $36 × 0.60 = $21.60

Price (P) at which margin call occurs:

Equity per share/Price per share = Maintenance margin (%)

($21.60 + P – $36)/P = 0.30

0.7P = $14.40

P = $20.57
answerFeedback.d4d02d7d-9a28-4f9e-9a65-8d0dfc25dce0: Incorrect because it takes (1 – maintenance margin %) of the initial price as the critical price for margin call: $36 × (1 – 0.3) = $25.20.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-30
entry.itemBody: The type of developed market bond that most likely has the greatest risk of default is a:

answerFeedback.273d59c4-053a-492a-ab47-907179edd50c: Incorrect because general obligation bonds are less risky than revenue bonds but more risky than sovereign debt. Government bonds in developed countries have traditionally been viewed as the default risk-free rate off of which all other credits are priced. Revenue bonds, which are issued to finance a specific project, have a higher degree of risk than GO (general obligation) bonds because they are dependent on a single source of revenue.
answerFeedback.d3adb634-3b1f-45c1-818e-7f4d1097f54a: Correct because revenue bonds have greater risk than both sovereign debt and general obligation bonds. Government bonds in developed countries have traditionally been viewed as the default risk-free rate off of which all other credits are priced. Revenue bonds, which are issued to finance a specific project, have a higher degree of risk than GO (general obligation) bonds because they are dependent on a single source of revenue.
answerFeedback.e3f7c27e-f875-41c3-84c9-5f788268fa45: Incorrect because sovereign debt in developed markets is the least risky among bond market segments because sovereigns have the ability to use monetary policy, unlike non-sovereign governments. Government bonds in developed countries have traditionally been viewed as the default risk-free rate off of which all other credits are priced.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516158
entry.itemBody: An index provider launches a new index that will include value stocks in a specific country. This index will most likely be a:

answerFeedback.14de3244-d446-4c0e-b67b-258d3567ab29: Incorrect because large-capitalization indexes represent and track the largest securities in terms of market capitalization. They do not represent the category of value stocks.
answerFeedback.18255ecf-436f-4b2b-a6d5-b8fcd62ac7ae: Incorrect because fundamentally weighted indexes use measures such as book value, cash flow, revenues, earnings, dividends, and number of employees to weight the constituent securities. Securities of different styles and sectors could be included in the same fundamentally weighted index. Therefore, fundamentally weighted indexes do not represent the category of value stocks.
answerFeedback.9faaab31-c140-4280-b63e-3b02fa52f5ac: Correct because style indexes represent a group of securities classified according to market capitalization, value, and growth or a combination of these characteristics. Therefore, the new index will most likely be a style index with a value classification.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Bailey-14
entry.itemBody: If a market is semi-strong-form efficient, fundamental analysis most likely:

answerFeedback.0a76928b-4bcd-4aab-bc94-6cfeb413a7ca: Correct because fundamental analysis is necessary in a well-functioning market because this analysis helps market participants understand the value implications of information.
answerFeedback.7457c921-2dd5-4ebf-b678-0d01a7334912: Incorrect because fundamental analysis is the examination of publicly available information and the formulation of forecasts to estimate the intrinsic value of assets. Instead, investors using technical analysis attempt to profit by looking at patterns of prices and trading volumes.
answerFeedback.ca3f182e-671e-4cc9-bfc4-4b6701e953b1: Incorrect because if securities markets are weak-form and semi-strong-form efficient, the implication is that active trading, whether attempting to exploit price patterns or public information, is not likely to generate abnormal returns. And, although fundamental analysis requires costly information, this analysis can be profitable in terms of generating abnormal returns if the analyst creates a comparative advantage with respect to this information; however, this is not "most likely".  Portfolio managers cannot beat the market on a consistent basis.

choices.itemBody: A. enables investors to generate consistent abnormal returns.
B. helps participants understand the value implications of information.
C. attempts to profit by looking at patterns of prices and trading volumes.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-16
entry.itemBody: The yield-to-maturity of a 5-year, 8% annual-pay bond priced at 108.42 is closest to:

answerFeedback.13113177-8a35-4b3f-87d4-52ef7321d10f: Incorrect because the yield-to-maturity is the discount rate, r, that equates the price of the bond to the present value of the coupon payments and par value. This answer reverses the purchase price and the par value: 8/(1+r) + 8/(1+r)2 + 8/(1+r)3 + 8/(1+r)4 + (108.42+8)/(1+r)5 = 100, r ≈ 9.40%. N=5, PV= –100, PMT=8, FV=108.42, I/Y ≈ 9.40%.
answerFeedback.14043ce6-75f8-4898-ac44-f390be0cba9a: Correct because the yield-to-maturity is the discount rate, r, that equates the price of the bond to the present value of the coupon payments and par value: 8/(1+r) + 8/(1+r)2 + 8/(1+r)3 + 8/(1+r)4 + 108/(1+r)5 = 108.42, r = 6.00%. N=5, PV= –108.42, PMT=8, FV=100, I/Y = 6.00%.
answerFeedback.dfe45040-d440-4fb8-b2df-0259ab06d0d2: Incorrect because the yield-to-maturity is the discount rate, r, that equates the price of the bond to the present value of the coupon payments and par value. This answer computes the current yield instead of the yield to maturity. The current yield is the sum of the coupon payments received over the year divided by the flat price. 8/108.42 ≈ 7.38%.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516049
entry.itemBody: For an option-free bond, effective duration:

answerFeedback.0c8a0fb2-1636-4be1-a696-8f6f2df6efd8: Incorrect because effective duration is a curve duration statistic that measures interest rate risk in terms of a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve (not a change in the bond’s own yield to maturity). Yield duration statistics, such as Macaulay duration and modified duration, measure interest rate risk in terms of a change in the bond’s own yield to maturity.
answerFeedback.1ab02cf0-51d0-4aa0-a5cf-a5cba30b6a47: Incorrect because effective duration is a curve duration statistic that measures interest rate risk in terms of a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve, assuming all yields change by the same amount. Interest rate sensitivity associated with non-parallel yield curve shifts is measured by key rate duration rather than effective duration.
answerFeedback.96754b50-c858-4abb-be2a-530c33dfaca1: Correct because the effective duration and modified duration of an option-free bond are identical only in the rare circumstance of an absolutely flat yield curve. Typically, the two duration measures will differ, but the difference narrows when the yield curve is flatter, the bond’s time to maturity is shorter, and the bond is priced closer to its par value.

choices.itemBody: A. will be equal to modified duration if the yield curve is absolutely flat.
B. measures interest rate risk for both parallel and non-parallel benchmark yield curve shifts.
C. is an estimate of the percentage change in bond price given a change in the bond’s yield to maturity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-05
entry.itemBody: Bonds issued in which of the following markets most likely have fewer reporting, regulatory, and tax constraints?

answerFeedback.ab90124a-4fbe-4e7f-aa0d-aeb92896c725: Incorrect because the Eurobond market has traditionally been characterized by fewer reporting, regulatory, and tax constraints than domestic and foreign bond markets.
answerFeedback.d4191e9e-cb26-48f2-89f9-3f5dbac07c73: Incorrect because the Eurobond market has traditionally been characterized by fewer reporting, regulatory, and tax constraints than domestic and foreign bond markets.
answerFeedback.f8d4783c-5aba-4ea2-8793-e49a6ba644bb: Correct because domestic and foreign bonds are subject to the legal, regulatory, and tax requirements that apply in that particular country. In contrast, a Eurobond is issued internationally, outside the jurisdiction of the country in whose currency the bond is denominated. The Eurobond market has traditionally been characterized by fewer reporting, regulatory, and tax constraints than domestic and foreign bond markets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10294
entry.itemBody: The correlation between the returns of a risk-free asset and a portfolio of risky assets is:

answerFeedback.4586c795-c714-457f-bfbf-0b681d9aadea: Incorrect because a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset.
answerFeedback.96ba86da-2be8-4bfb-93b8-4134a36bfb08: Incorrect because a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset.
answerFeedback.f3ffa585-bc1c-4aa8-833e-0ae431dde220: Correct because a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607117
entry.itemBody: A 6% 25-year bond with semiannual payments has a market price of $850.00. The yield to maturity of this bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.5262b454-f3db-4f30-878f-750a31fc7041:
Correct. The yield to maturity is the discount rate that equates the price of the bond ($850.00) with its cash flows (49 semiannual cash flows of $30 and a 50th cash flow of $1,030), or

$850 = $30/(1+YTM/2)1 +  $30/(1+YTM/2)2 +...+ $1030/(1+YTM/2)50

Using a financial calculator to find the yield to maturity gives 7.32%.
answerFeedback.c5ef65a9-ec4c-4507-95e6-2ba8b87238de: Incorrect because this is the YTM found when setting a calculator for 2 payments per year but inputting only 25 payments, rather than 50.
answerFeedback.ddf4584b-9e54-4531-94f8-59b147bdf04a: Incorrect because this is the YTM found when reversing the price and face value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Groenning-15
entry.itemBody: The motivation for investing in the mezzanine tranche of a collateralized debt obligation (CDO) is most likely to:

answerFeedback.9a780415-8476-4b10-bf99-840a6a64725b: Incorrect because it is the senior bond tranche that benefits from credit protection from the mezzanine bond tranche as in any waterfall structure. The subordinated bond classes are sometimes called 'non-senior bond classes' or 'junior bond classes.' They function as credit protection for the more senior bond classes; that is, losses are realized by the subordinated bond classes before any losses are realized by the senior bond classes. Also, the CDO is constructed so as to impose restrictions on the CDO manager via various tests and limits that must be satisfied for the CDO to meet investors’ varying risk appetites while still providing adequate protection for the senior bond class. If the CDO manager fails pre-specified tests, a provision is triggered that requires the payoff of the principal to the senior bond class until the tests are satisfied.
answerFeedback.b5c85ea0-87e5-4854-b348-49814473fbff: Incorrect because this reflects the motivation to invest in the equity tranche, not in the mezzanine tranche. The funds to purchase the collateral assets for a CDO are obtained from the issuance of debt obligations. These debt obligations are bond classes or tranches and include senior bond classes, mezzanine bond classes (that is, bond classes with credit ratings between senior and subordinated bond classes), and subordinated bond classes, often referred to as the residual or equity tranches. The CDO manager seeks to earn a rate of return higher than the aggregate cost of the bond classes (senior bond and mezzanine bond classes). The return in excess of what is paid out to the bond classes accrues to the holders of the equity tranche and to the CDO manager.
answerFeedback.d4df4df5-1102-4979-acb5-00a1d3ad2a34: Correct because the motivation for investors to invest in senior or mezzanine bond classes is to earn a potentially higher yield than that on a comparably rated corporate bond by gaining exposure to debt products that they may not otherwise be able to purchase.

choices.itemBody: A. benefit from the credit protection provided by the senior tranche.
B. earn a higher yield than that on a comparably rated corporate bond.
C. ﻿receive a return in excess of what is paid out to all other bond classes.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08337
entry.itemBody:
An investor holds a bond with the following characteristics:

Yield to maturity 10%
Modified duration 5.7

If the duration gap is zero, the investment horizon is closest to:

answerFeedback.2959de8d-03e3-4be0-88e1-42600ab90db7: Incorrect because the candidate confuses the Macaulay duration with the modified duration, thus incorrectly determining the investment horizon as 5.7 years.
answerFeedback.58d0f094-30d7-4bdf-b055-8bfabdcdecc8: Incorrect because the candidate calculates the Macaulay duration incorrectly: MacDur ≠ 5.7 / (1 + 10%) = 5.18, or 5.2. Because the duration gap is equal to the bond's Macaulay duration minus the investment horizon the investment horizon is incorrectly stated as 5.2 years.
answerFeedback.e7a9f2d7-d06c-42e6-b979-04fcef178c03: Correct because we use the fact that ModDur = MacDur / (1 + r) to calculate the Macaulay duration of the bond: MacDur = 5.7 × (1 + 10%) = 6.27, or 6.3.  Because the duration gap is equal to the bond's Macaulay duration minus the investment horizon the investment horizon is closest to 6.3 years.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03051
entry.itemBody: The CAPM states that two assets with the same expected return will have the same:

answerFeedback.7b6267f3-6ed0-4a78-b79b-51f70f2fd6bc: Incorrect because the CAPM asserts that the expected returns of assets vary only by their systematic risk as measured by beta. However, as beta captures an asset's systematic risk and ignores nonsystematic risk, the assets' total risk (measured by their standard deviations) may differ even though their betas are equal.
answerFeedback.c8edb21d-4c5d-42c9-8538-472f5ab4d730: Incorrect because βi = ρi,mσi / σm. As beta captures an asset's systematic risk and ignores nonsystematic risk, the assets' total risk (measured by their standard deviations) may differ even though their betas and expected returns are equal. When σi is different for each asset, ρi,m will have to be different for each asset if the betas are equal.
answerFeedback.e567807f-d929-49d1-a8fd-da141b9eecaa: Correct because the CAPM asserts that the expected returns of assets vary only by their systematic risk as measured by beta. Two assets with the same beta will have the same expected return irrespective of the nature of those assets. The covariance of an asset with the market is defined as βiσm2. Therefore, assets with the same expected return and thus the same beta will have the same covariance of returns with the market.

choices.itemBody: B. correlation of returns with the market.
C. covariance of returns with the market.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Georgiou-03
entry.itemBody: The sensitivity of a 30-year fixed-rate bond to a 50 basis points increase in the benchmark rate at the 25-30 years maturity segment is best measured by:

answerFeedback.2973fe00-425a-4dd3-b0de-c2a6ab0a2fdc: Incorrect because modified duration provides an estimate of the percentage price change for a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.54b0e783-ca04-45fe-be79-a054ed7a32d0: Incorrect because effective duration is a curve duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve (ΔCurve).
answerFeedback.d93cb5e1-bc70-4356-8771-3136992d31b3: Correct because key rate duration provides further insight into a bond’s sensitivity to changes in the benchmark yield curve. A key rate duration (or partial duration) is a measure of a bond’s sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield curve at a specific maturity segment.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lamba-01
entry.itemBody: A put option trades for $1.00 with an exercise price of $40.00. If the price of the underlying at expiration is $35.00, the profit for a put seller is:

answerFeedback.3118abdd-65d4-45d0-a7c8-42a04f9dee16: Incorrect because the put buyer’s (not seller’s) profit is calculated as: Max(0, X – ST) – p0 = Max(0, $40.00 – $35.00) – $1.00 = $4.00.
answerFeedback.7ab32603-9c32-4cee-bfeb-123b45c37657: Incorrect because the put seller’s payoff (not profit) is calculated as: –Max(0, X – ST) = –Max(0, $40.00 – $35.00) = –$5.00.
answerFeedback.9f0e7800-4921-476d-89c3-86abd753ed4d:
Correct because the put seller’s profit is: Π = –Max(0, X – ST) + p0 , where

X = exercise price

ST = strike price

p0 = price of put option

 

Plugging in the values:

Π = –Max(0, $40.00 – $35.00) + $1.00 = –$4.00.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Fairborn-14
entry.itemBody: Investing in private debt most likely is:

answerFeedback.30540b4f-dbad-4b33-a48e-6a49a60947ff: Correct because investing in private debt is riskier than investing in traditional bonds. Investors should be aware of these risks, including illiquidity and heightened default risk when loans are extended to riskier entities or borrowers in riskier situations.
answerFeedback.a4287f89-74db-4f02-9137-46269a6fb180: Incorrect because investing in private debt is riskier than investing in traditional bonds. Investors should be aware of these risks, including illiquidity and heightened default risk when loans are extended to riskier entities or borrowers in riskier situations.
answerFeedback.b54d12ec-144e-4034-a3d1-96de9ac7cd82: Incorrect because investing in private debt is riskier than investing in traditional bonds. Investors should be aware of these risks, including illiquidity and heightened default risk when loans are extended to riskier entities or borrowers in riskier situations.

choices.itemBody: A. less risky than investing in traditional bonds.
B. equally risky to investing in traditional bonds.
C. more risky than investing in traditional bonds.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607032
entry.itemBody: An investor purchases a 5% coupon bond maturing in 15 years for par value. Immediately after purchase, the yield required by the market increases. The investor would then most likely have to sell the bond at:

answerFeedback.1d12732d-97a4-47fe-accd-04a778c06ffd: Correct because the bond would sell below par or at a discount if the yield required by the market rises above the coupon rate. Because the bond initially was purchased at par, the coupon rate equals the yield required by the market. Subsequently, if yields rise above the coupon, the bond’s market price would fall below par.
answerFeedback.58d65ba2-bf8d-4ec1-8153-1f740c2a230d: Incorrect because the yield is now greater than the coupon.
answerFeedback.a5bdec8e-a6f5-48bf-b740-9c98ba2899f5: Incorrect because the yield is now greater than the coupon.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-16
entry.itemBody: If a semiannual pay bond has a yield-to-maturity of 4.3% quoted on a semiannual bond basis, the yield-to-maturity based on quarterly compounding is closest to:

answerFeedback.3c5f1213-ffab-4819-8a85-00d2ea4a6e58:
Incorrect because the formula converts from quarterly to semi-annual compounding:

(1 + (APR/2))2 = (1 + (APR/4))4

(1 + (APR/2))2 = (1 + (0.043/4))4

APR ≠ 0.043231 ≈ 4.32%.
answerFeedback.bc1445ab-ed8b-4d37-bb62-19d6c52b72fa:
Correct because the formula to convert from semi-annual to quarterly compounding is:

(1 + (APR/2))2 = (1 + (APR/4))4

(1 + (0.043/2))2 = (1 + (APR/4))4

APR = 0.042771 ≈ 4.28%.
answerFeedback.f0892ff6-5962-46bd-9adb-bdad618b5a65:
Incorrect because the formula converts from annual to quarterly compounding:

(1 + (APR/1))1 = (1 + (APR/4))4 

(1 + (0.43)) = (1 + (APR/4))4

APR ≠ 0.042324 ≈ 4.23%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Bangaruswamy-01
entry.itemBody: The value of a European put is:

answerFeedback.0649a6c5-acb4-4e43-92fa-3a03626285b8: Correct because the value of a European put is inversely related to the risk-free interest rate.
answerFeedback.65a24b11-bea2-457d-be5b-6185fc1eed98: Incorrect because the value of a European put option is inversely related to the value of the underlying.
answerFeedback.aea0aeca-0c62-48f5-b545-39391b0722a1: Incorrect because the value of a European put option is directly related to the exercise price.

choices.itemBody: A. inversely related to the exercise price.
B. inversely related to the risk-free interest rate.
C. directly related to the value of the underlying.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516042
entry.itemBody: An asset-based valuation model would be most applicable:

answerFeedback.226f1f78-ceeb-41a5-bbe5-953ec5a29a08: Correct because owners of small, privately held businesses are familiar with valuations arrived at by valuing the assets of the company and then subtracting any relevant liabilities.
answerFeedback.48d3ed38-53be-47cf-85e0-7c5384236330: Incorrect because companies with assets that do not have easily determinable market (fair) values—such as those with significant property, plant, and equipment—are very difficult to analyze using asset-based valuation methods.
answerFeedback.a756a7a7-8cfe-435a-9456-e9bcca17f792: Incorrect because asset values may be more difficult to estimate in a hyperinflationary environment.

choices.itemBody: A. for valuing a small and privately held firm.
B. when the economic environment is hyperinflationary.
C. for valuing a firm that has significant property, plant, and equipment.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427071
entry.itemBody: A disadvantage of a fund of hedge funds as compared to a large multi-strategy fund is:

answerFeedback.6a35ed2c-a4c7-4c70-965e-602bca32c52a: Incorrect because due diligence expertise is one of the advantages that funds of hedge funds may offer but multi-strategy funds do not. Fund-of-hedge-fund managers must have expertise in conducting hedge fund due diligence, must monitor both absolute and relative performance, and are often able to negotiate better redemption or fee terms than individual investors can.
answerFeedback.a8a5f6cf-82d8-4df0-ae46-e567044ba203: Correct because funds of hedge funds will add an extra layer of fees. For the investor, all this comes with a higher fee structure—often an additional 1%—because the manager of the fund of funds adds its own fees on top of the hedge fund management fees. Fund-of-funds investors often face a 10% incentive fee in addition to those fees charged by underlying hedge funds.
answerFeedback.ba50a6a9-4518-470a-9eb2-0ab5337d2708: Incorrect because a large multi-strategy fund can also provide a diversification over various hedge fund strategies. Multi-strategy funds trade relative value within and across asset classes or instruments. Rather than focusing on one type of trade (e.g., convertible arbitrage), a single basis for a trade (e.g., merger arbitrage), or a particular asset class (e.g., fixed income), this strategy instead looks for any available investment opportunities, often with different pods of managers executing unique market approaches.

choices.itemBody: C. diversified exposure to various hedge fund strategies.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lamba-08
entry.itemBody: For a put option, if the price of the underlying is greater than the exercise price, the put option is:

answerFeedback.058b1498-1125-45fa-8138-51e97e05b7f0: Incorrect because when the underlying is precisely at the exercise price, the option is said to be at the money.
answerFeedback.06f5eeab-ebe8-419b-a61a-3f20c12d9de0: Incorrect because when the underlying is below the put exercise price, the option is said to be in the money.
answerFeedback.2a91db44-0a6d-4db1-ab78-200b28c1b5a5: Correct because when the underlying is higher than the exercise price of the put option, the option is said to be out of the money.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Glover-03
entry.itemBody: As compared to exchange-traded derivative markets, over-the-counter derivative markets are typically more:

answerFeedback.24ea37f1-1b33-4ba3-bc06-3eb4c3115088: Incorrect because OTC instruments have less transparency, usually involve more counterparty risk, and may be less liquid. Moreover, when compared to OTC derivative markets, ETD contracts are more formal and standardized, which facilitates a more liquid and transparent market. Hence, OTC derivative markets are typically less, not more, liquid than ETD markets.
answerFeedback.4eee3e58-bee5-4c4d-8773-bdb8d60ebd13: Incorrect because ETD markets have transparency, which means that full information on all transactions is disclosed to exchanges and national regulators. Moreover, when compared to OTC derivative markets, ETD contracts are more formal and standardized, which facilitates a more liquid and transparent market. Hence, OTC derivative markets are typically less, not more, transparent than ETD markets.
answerFeedback.511e63ba-01d5-4151-8fd3-ef860754ffee: Correct because OTC (over-the-counter) and ETD (exchange-traded derivative) markets differ in several ways. OTC derivatives offer greater flexibility and customization than ETD. Specifically, the terms of OTC contracts can be customized to match a desired risk exposure profile. This flexibility is important to end users seeking to hedge a specific existing or anticipated underlying exposure based upon non-standard terms.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427066
entry.itemBody: With regard to commodities, it is most likely true that:

answerFeedback.65e06b07-f8ec-48c0-b916-00f5740d7361: Incorrect because commodities themselves do not generate cash flows but usually incur costs (cost of carry).
answerFeedback.bb666558-36db-4eae-9081-90eafe5d70f7: Correct because the majority of commodity investing is implemented through derivatives.
answerFeedback.bf1598c5-0350-4c64-9873-68c5ae1b3b04: Correct because the majority of commodity investing is implemented through derivatives (not physical commodities).

choices.itemBody: A. exposure is most commonly achieved via commodity derivatives.
B. their returns are based on an income stream such as interest or dividends.
C. they are physical products so most investors prefer to trade the actual commodity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Hung-10
entry.itemBody:
An analyst forecasts different outcomes for a company next year:

  Bear Case Base Case Bull Case
Sales (In € millions) 280 350 400
EBITDA margin (%) 10 18 25
Debt to capital (%) 75 60 55

This forecast table is best described as a:

answerFeedback.0e315092-7256-4b0a-b0b6-2cc34a690330: Incorrect because this is a scenario analysis, not sensitivity analysis.
answerFeedback.1b988c68-bf45-49a4-9d2f-a7ee7fe04844: Incorrect because this is a scenario analysis, not a point estimate forecast.
answerFeedback.3134bc45-9c34-40c8-83a2-5ae8006c8162: Correct because scenario analysis involves incorporating the possibility of different outcomes based on key risk factors as well as judging their likelihood of occurrence. Generic risk factors that affect all companies—but to varying degrees include changes in the business cycle, competition, inflation and deflation, and technological developments. Rather than develop single point estimate forecasts, analysts make several forecast scenarios that vary based on different outcomes with respect to key risk factors.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601026
entry.itemBody: During its life, the value of a forward contract is most likely equal to the price of the underlying minus the price of the:

answerFeedback.9663901c-5147-4e83-b33f-082d9e792d01: Correct. The value of a forward contract is the spot price of the underlying minus the present value of the forward contract. Calculating the present value requires adjusting the time period to account for the remaining term of the contract.
answerFeedback.db58e680-4c72-4787-959e-4f8158384f3f: Incorrect. This is only true at expiration.
answerFeedback.f54aad76-8bab-4663-b388-864c7e81ed1a: Incorrect. This is only true at initiation.

choices.itemBody: B. forward, discounted over the original term of the contract.
C. forward, discounted over the remaining term of the contract.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00812
entry.itemBody: According to the capital asset pricing model (CAPM), the difference in the expected returns for two securities is determined by the securities':

answerFeedback.3199fb1d-75f1-41e2-9e19-18dcf6d47c38: Correct because the CAPM asserts that the expected returns of assets vary only by their systematic risk as measured by beta. Two assets with the same beta will have the same expected return irrespective of the nature of those assets.
answerFeedback.361c6ce8-6734-412d-b84b-801c8ea3acd8: Incorrect because the standard deviation is a measure of total risk or volatility of a security itself based on historical returns. A security's standard deviation, correlation, and the standard deviation of the market must be taken into account in the calculation for beta, a measure of systematic risk. According to the CAPM, it is beta (systematic risk) that is then used to calculate expected return, because the nonsystematic risk included in the total risk (standard deviation) can be diversified away. Thus, while standard deviation is used to determine beta, the CAPM asserts that the expected returns of assets vary only by their systematic risk as measured by beta. Two assets with the same beta will have the same expected return irrespective of the nature of those assets.
answerFeedback.8c997015-5647-4a06-8b52-6cc101b95787: Incorrect because the CAPM asserts that the expected returns of assets vary only by their systematic risk as measured by beta. Two assets with the same beta will have the same expected return irrespective of the nature of those assets. Nonsystematic risk is not part of the expected return of a security.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Elkinawy-Young-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following performance measures is most appropriate for an investor who holds a well-diversified portfolio?

answerFeedback.356108ce-60b1-4ed5-a22f-0c7102bc0186: Correct because Jensen's alpha is based on systematic risk. Performance measures relative to beta risk—Treynor ratio and Jensen’s alpha—are relevant when the investor holds a well-diversified portfolio with negligible diversifiable risk.
answerFeedback.58524220-129c-4dee-acdc-321514d4c423: Incorrect because a well-diversified investor is only exposed to systematic risk, as measured by beta. The Sharpe ratio uses the total risk of the portfolio, not its systematic risk. Total risk is relevant for an investor when he or she holds a portfolio that is not fully diversified.
answerFeedback.b8e84e38-e820-4809-8a35-b2d7544e7a1c: Incorrect because M2 utilizes total risk rather than systematic risk. Total risk is relevant for an investor when he or she holds a portfolio that is not fully diversified, which is not a desirable portfolio. In such cases, the Sharpe ratio and M2 are appropriate performance measures.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03827
entry.itemBody: A function of the financial system is to:

answerFeedback.91e8ce39-1e3f-4e8b-97d2-8874ef1115d1: Incorrect because a main function of the financial system is to facilitate the achievement of the purposes for which people use the financial system. People use the financial system for six main purposes, one of which is to trade on information. Information-motivated traders trade to profit from information that they believe allows them to predict future prices.
answerFeedback.bb7328e0-ca22-40c7-ab32-4a769d758782: Incorrect because the main functions of the financial system are to facilitate which includes the achievement of the purposes for which people use the financial system. People use the financial system for six main purposes, one of which is to borrow money for current use. People, companies, and governments often want to spend money now that they do not have. They can obtain money to fund projects that they wish to undertake now by borrowing it.
answerFeedback.e2e022d8-50b3-4140-b51c-5bec45b28391: Correct because the main functions of the financial system are to facilitate, which includes the discovery of the rates of return that equate aggregate savings with aggregate borrowings. Economists call this rate the equilibrium interest rate. It is the price for moving money through time. Determining this rate is one of the most important functions of the financial system.

choices.itemBody: C. restrict companies from spending money they do not have.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Deriv 05GXH 09U1
entry.itemBody: A protective put strategy consists of a:

answerFeedback.0bf37a45-2861-4f0b-ae30-d4445cc0882a: Incorrect because the strategy of holding the asset and a put is called a protective put. A protective put does not consist of a long put option on an asset and a long position in a risk-free bond.
answerFeedback.0bf38b05-3147-4510-8522-4a8eb7b537f9: Incorrect because the strategy of holding the asset and a put is called a protective put. A protective put does not consist of a long call option on an asset and a short position in the underlying asset.
answerFeedback.8baa6155-6781-451c-bf6c-f38a1e9b94e0: Correct because the strategy of holding the asset and a put is called a protective put.

choices.itemBody: A. long put option on an asset and a long position in a risk-free bond.
B. long position in an underlying asset and a long put option on the asset.
C. long call option on an asset and a short position in the underlying asset.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-12
entry.itemBody: A stock dividend:

answerFeedback.37de52fb-a281-480c-bd44-9587bf13ff8d: Incorrect because a stock dividend divides the “pie” (the market value of shareholders’ equity) into smaller pieces without affecting the value of the pie or any shareholder’s proportional ownership in the company.
answerFeedback.95955fcc-344a-4c23-a2f5-6b38530c32d6: Incorrect because stock dividends are not relevant for valuation.
answerFeedback.d0d3eb5b-6bf0-45fa-9f02-57d3d9909758: Correct because a stock dividend is a type of dividend in which a company distributes additional shares of its common stock (typically, 2%–10% of the shares then outstanding) to shareholders instead of cash. This results in an increase in the number of shares outstanding.

choices.itemBody: A. is relevant for valuation of a company.
B. involves an increase in the number of shares outstanding.
C. alters the shareholders' proportional ownership in the company.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Tomter-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following best describes a reason for having a written investment policy statement?

answerFeedback.87de9aa8-7229-44b7-a44e-813dae9e0b19: Correct because without a full understanding of the client's situation and requirements, it is unlikely that successful results will be achieved. 'Success' can be defined as a client achieving his or her important investment goals using means that he or she is comfortable with (in terms of risks taken and other concerns). The IPS essentially communicates a plan for achieving investment success.
answerFeedback.8ea5e3d6-aa53-4f4b-8d02-71ddb82e4d6f: Incorrect because the IPS is prepared before a client's investment portfolio is constructed as part of portfolio planning. Portfolio planning can be defined as a program developed in advance of constructing a portfolio that is expected to define the client’s investment objectives. The written document governing this process is the IPS. Although Evaluation and Review is a component of the finished document, the reason for having a written IPS is to provide investment guidelines, not to track performance.
answerFeedback.c688de0c-a7d8-4199-8452-b2f038343227: Incorrect because a determination of the client's risk tolerance is done before writing the IPS. The IPS is typically developed following a fact-finding discussion with the client. This fact-finding discussion can include the use of a questionnaire designed to articulate the client's risk tolerance as well as specific circumstances.

choices.itemBody: A. To communicate a plan for achieving investment success
B. To keep track of the performance of a client's investment portfolio
C. To serve as a fact-finding process for determining a client's risk tolerance

entry.title: ITEM_20190531020
entry.itemBody: Which bond is most likely to exhibit a reduction in duration as time to maturity increases? A bond priced at:

answerFeedback.7d004cbb-12ff-44e8-807b-90f81b16cd3e: Incorrect because for par and premium bonds, longer times to maturity always correspond to higher duration measures (interest rate risk).
answerFeedback.a8a9cdd7-ed59-4288-b424-d8b33d1598cb: Incorrect because for par and premium bonds, longer times to maturity always correspond to higher duration measures (interest rate risk).
answerFeedback.e442a6da-99d7-4557-9bc6-f29b94a224e1: Correct because a longer time to maturity usually leads to higher duration. It always does so for a bond priced at a premium or par value. But if the bond is priced at a discount, a longer time to maturity might lead to a lower duration. The situation occurs only if the coupon rate is low (but not zero) relative to the yield and the time to maturity is long.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06272
entry.itemBody: In the investment policy statement of a pension fund, a countrywide limit on the proportion of high-risk assets that can be held in long-term pension portfolios is most likely a:

answerFeedback.80fe6461-2aa1-4902-9807-f5dc429b24b8: Incorrect because the countrywide constraint for pension funds that limits the proportion of high-risk assets in the portfolio is a regulatory constraint. The fact that the constraint is formulated as a limit to invest in high-risk assets does not indicate it is a liquidity constraint. Liquidity constraints state what the likely requirements are to withdraw funds from the portfolio.
answerFeedback.b0295c4e-2e30-43ca-a5b5-28516cff7a8d: Correct because the IPS should state any legal and regulatory restrictions that constrain how the portfolio is invested. In some countries, such institutional investors as pension funds are subject to restrictions on the composition of the portfolio. For example, there may be a limit on the proportion of equities or other risky assets in the portfolio, or on the proportion of the portfolio that may be invested overseas.
answerFeedback.f5b98448-cef9-4b38-aa7a-26bcc4e0478d: Incorrect because the countrywide constraint for pension funds that limits the proportion of high-risk assets in the portfolio is a regulatory constraint. The constraint does not change the broad investment time horizon of the pension fund and is therefore not a time horizon constraint. Time horizon constraints state the time horizon over which the investor is investing.

entry.title: ITEM_20190531004
entry.itemBody: Relative to a non-recourse mortgage loan, in a recourse mortgage loan the:

answerFeedback.2ce151db-1ed1-44d7-ae63-9341a98161ea: Correct because there are recourse and non-recourse mortgage loans. In a non-recourse loan, the lender does not have a claim against the borrower and thus can look only to the property to recover the outstanding mortgage balance. In a recourse loan, the lender can seek to recover any shortfall from the sale of the property to cover the mortgage loan. The borrower, therefore, has a strategic default option only in non-recourse loans; for example, if the mortgage is greater than the property value, he may select to default without further personal obligation.
answerFeedback.de849e39-892b-44e1-ab6a-15b1d28d13b0: Incorrect because recourse and non-recourse do not refer to any pricing terms.
answerFeedback.f884b727-c764-43f7-873e-a25d756d6a4b: Incorrect because in a recourse loan, the borrower does not have an incentive to default on an underwater mortgage since the lender can seek to recover any shortfall beyond the sale of the property from the borrower.

choices.itemBody: A. lender can change the interest rate charged.
B. borrower does not have a strategic default option.
C. borrower is not liable for any shortfall between the property sale proceeds and the loan amount.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Tsependa-09
entry.itemBody: The multiple of invested capital (MOIC) measure takes into account:

answerFeedback.000155b7-3da9-4543-903b-88c1a7197310: Correct because MOIC is calculated as follows: MOIC = (Realized value of investment + Unrealized (or residual) value of investment)/(Total amount of invested capital). With MOIC, one simply measures the total value of all realized investments and residual asset values (assets that may still be awaiting their ultimate sale) relative to an initial total investment.
answerFeedback.0392486e-4cee-4b7b-9e89-0ea3e7004f34: Incorrect because MOIC is calculated as follows: MOIC = (Realized value of investment + Unrealized (or residual) value of investment)/(Total amount of invested capital). With MOIC, one simply measures the total value of all realized investments and residual asset values (assets that may still be awaiting their ultimate sale) relative to an initial total investment.
answerFeedback.85a958fc-aaff-4460-914b-8285e8078fb2: Incorrect because MOIC is calculated as follows: MOIC = (Realized value of investment + Unrealized (or residual) value of investment)/(Total amount of invested capital). With MOIC, one simply measures the total value of all realized investments and residual asset values (assets that may still be awaiting their ultimate sale) relative to an initial total investment.

choices.itemBody: A. the realized value of an investment only.
B. the residual asset value of an investment only.
C. both the realized value of an investment and the residual asset value of an investment.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Tomter-03
entry.itemBody: Investors in a closed-end mutual fund can liquidate their positions by selling the shares to:

answerFeedback.2b42dcc9-4df8-4fe8-82f3-6ae304ed8c9a: Correct because an alternative to setting the fund up as an open-end fund would be to create a closed-end fund in which no new investment money is accepted into the fund. New investors invest by buying existing shares, and investors in the fund liquidate by selling their shares to other investors.
answerFeedback.ce294f91-2955-4c5b-aac3-a7833400e8ae: Incorrect because a closed-end fund investment is liquidated by selling the position to other investors in the market. An alternative to setting the fund up as an open-end fund would be to create a closed-end fund in which no new investment money is accepted into the fund. New investors invest by buying existing shares, and investors in the fund liquidate by selling their shares to other investors.
answerFeedback.dec78b0e-be90-407e-a5dd-33684143d455: Incorrect because this describes an open-end fund, not a closed-end fund. The fund can be set up as an open-end fund or a closed-end fund. If it is an open-end fund, it will accept new investment money and issue additional shares at a value equal to the net asset value of the fund at the time of investment. Funds can also be withdrawn at the net asset value per share. Suppose (an investor) wishes to withdraw all her shares in the mutual fund. To accommodate this withdrawal, the fund will have to liquidate assets to retire (the position). An alternative to setting the fund up as an open-end fund would be to create a closed-end fund in which no new investment money is accepted into the fund. New investors invest by buying existing shares, and investors in the fund liquidate by selling their shares to other investors.

choices.itemBody: C. both the fund itself and other investors.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-19
entry.itemBody: Effective duration measures a bond's sensitivity to a:

answerFeedback.41e2ffbe-f694-4488-9176-3195554cf290: Correct because effective duration measure indicates the bond’s sensitivity to the benchmark yield curve if all yields change by the same amount.
answerFeedback.782293b0-fae5-458c-9e07-233b87f7e2a2: Incorrect because effective duration measure indicates the bond’s sensitivity to the benchmark yield curve if all yields change by the same amount.
answerFeedback.a323ea4f-ff85-467b-a47a-83cb986760a7: Incorrect because effective duration measure indicates the bond’s sensitivity to the benchmark yield curve if all yields change by the same amount.

choices.itemBody: A. flattening of the benchmark yield curve.
B. steepening of the benchmark yield curve.
C. parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01704
entry.itemBody: An example of nonsystematic risk is a(n):

answerFeedback.21148f21-ca10-40a5-b42b-4d4ab806954c: Incorrect because a change in interest rates by the central bank is a systematic risk. Interest rate risk is non-diversifiable because it includes risk factors that are innate within the market and affect the market as a whole.
answerFeedback.afc4cc16-177d-4916-a1bf-7bb39eae1de3: Correct because nonsystematic risk is risk that is local or limited to a particular asset or industry that need not affect assets outside of that asset class. Examples of nonsystematic risk could include the failure of a drug trial, major oil discoveries, or an airliner crash. All these events will directly affect their respective companies and possibly industries, but have no effect on assets that are far removed from these industries. A change in the prescription drug approval process is an example of nonsystematic risk that is limited to the pharmaceutical industry.
answerFeedback.cc8dacdd-bccc-4300-b156-a043abf3de36: Incorrect because a change in the inflation rate is a systematic risk as it cannot be avoided. An increase in inflation will affect the market as a whole and not just a particular industry.

choices.itemBody: B. increase in the overall rate of inflation.
C. change in the central bank's interest rate policy.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Chua-03
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is best categorized as non-financial risk?

answerFeedback.499aa2c6-8fd0-43d3-b32e-295940afb001: Incorrect because the three primary types of financial risks are market risk, credit risk, and liquidity risk.
answerFeedback.8582c4e2-72cf-4c35-8c0b-112bd80285c9: Incorrect because the three primary types of financial risks are market risk, credit risk, and liquidity risk.
answerFeedback.f95e2294-bdeb-414b-a3b6-74d10ed7e299: Correct because the following three non-financial risks are related: regulatory risk, accounting risk, and tax risk, i.e., accounting risk is a non-financial risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Bailey-11
entry.itemBody: An investor buys a stock on margin, posting 60% of the initial $63.00 per share price as equity. All else being equal, if the investor receives a margin call at $33.60 per share, the maintenance margin on this trade is:

answerFeedback.06cf95f4-e2d0-4703-8b00-4d330b30f5a8: Incorrect because it calculates the margin requirement as 1 – initial equity = 1 – 0.6 = 0.4, which is 40%.
answerFeedback.66e75e91-cb24-4a90-9b01-2bb83a34d967: Correct because the maintenance margin = equity/share / price/share = (initial margin % × initial stock price + margin call price – initial price) / margin call price. In this case: (0.6 × $63 + $33.60 – $63) / $33.60 = ($37.8 + $33.60 – $63) / $33.60 = = $8.40 / $33.60 = 0.2500, which is closest to 25%.
answerFeedback.a83429b2-4705-4430-8334-15a822920820: Incorrect because it calculates the margin requirement as the initial equity per share minus the margin call price divided by the margin call price: (0.6 × $63 – $33.60) / 33.60 = $37.80 – $33.60 / $33.60 = $4.20 / $33.60 = 0.125, which is closest to 12.5%.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516037
entry.itemBody: Which version of the dividend discount model (DDM) would most likely be appropriate for valuing a fairly young, publicly traded company?

answerFeedback.2daba26d-5405-4d6f-bab0-954661ba4f86: Incorrect because a two-stage DDM would be appropriate to estimate the value of an older company that has already moved through its growth phase and is currently in the transition phase (a period with a growth rate higher than the sustainable growth rate) prior to moving to the maturity phase (the period with a lower, sustainable growth rate).
answerFeedback.72f1f53f-9c0f-4e28-b15b-063f0f9bc1e8: Correct because for most publicly traded companies (that is, companies beyond the startup stage), practitioners assume that growth will ultimately fall into three stages: (1) growth, (2) transition, and (3) maturity. This assumption supports the use of a three-stage DDM.
answerFeedback.e41d0fed-f316-4cc6-a97b-c81bc4decbdd: Incorrect because the Gordon growth model is a single-stage model that assumes that the dividend growth rate is perpetual and unchanging. This model is appropriate for a fully mature company with long-term sustainable prospects.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10040
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company and its common stock:

Current dividend per share (D0) $2.00
Dividend payout ratio 55%
ROE 9%

If the required return is 8%, the intrinsic value per share using the Gordon growth model is closest to:

answerFeedback.8b324bea-c1c0-49d2-b96e-41b22894a4f2: Incorrect because if the payout ratio is used instead of the retention rate to calculate the growth rate; then g = ROE × payout rate = 0.09 × 0.55 = 0.0495, D1 = D0 × (1 + g) = $2.00 × 1.0495 = $2.0990. Thus, V0 = $2.0990 / (0.08 – 0.0495) = $2.0990 / 0.0305 ≈ $68.8197 = $68.82.
answerFeedback.c43c5f4e-d7ca-40bd-9915-7d4e74803d8d: Correct because intrinsic value = V0 = D1 / (r – g), where: g = ROE × earnings retention rate = 0.09 × (1 – 0.55) = 0.0405, D1 = D0 × (1 + g) = $2.00 × 1.0405 = $2.0810. Thus, V0 = $2.0810 / (0.08 – 0.0405) = $2.0810 / 0.0395 ≈ $52.6835 = $52.68.
answerFeedback.ea99039e-1262-4e6d-adba-d6cbb77165e3: Incorrect because if D0 is used instead of D1, then intrinsic value V0 = D0 / (r – g), where: g = ROE × earnings retention rate = 0.09 × (1 – 0.55) = 0.0405. Thus, V0 = $2.00 / (0.08 – 0.0405) = $2.00 / 0.0395 ≈ $50.6329 = $50.63.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FRA-Roberts-24
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in £ millions) about a company's fiscal year:

Net income 1,500 
Average total assets 11,500 
Average shareholders' equity 7,500 

If the dividend payout ratio is 45%, the sustainable growth rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.52500384-6011-45c1-b42c-0d45ac54142f:
Incorrect because it assumed the sustainable growth rate = Payout ratio × ROE, where ROE = Net income / Average shareholders' equity = 1,500 / 7,500 = 0.2.

Thus sustainable growth rate is calculated as = 0.45 × 0.2 = 0.09 = 9%.
answerFeedback.79247117-07ea-4564-9175-878f968fc5ef:
