Incorrect because it assumed the sustainable growth rate = (1 – payout ratio) × ROA, where ROA = Net income / Average total assets = 1,500/11,500 = 0.1304. 

Thus the sustainable growth rate = (1 – 0.45) × 0.1304 = 0.55 × 0.1304 = 0.0717 ≈ 7%.
answerFeedback.d1c48ac6-565c-4d07-afb2-aa0f08930965:
Correct because the sustainable growth rate = Retention rate × ROE, where the retention rate = (1– payout ratio) and ROE = Net income / Average shareholders' equity.

Thus sustainable growth rate = (1 – 0.45) × 1,500/7,500 = 0.55 × 0.2 = 0.11 = 11%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01907
entry.itemBody: Which of the following most likely accounts for most of the long-term changes in a portfolio's value?

answerFeedback.0ae7e033-e5d3-4bfb-ade5-4e61bc6ba972: Incorrect because security selection is an attempt to generate higher returns than the asset class benchmark by selecting securities with a higher expected return. In other words, security selection creates alpha. But it is beta, and not alpha that accounts for most of the changes in a portfolio's value over the long term.
answerFeedback.0b849f63-c0d5-436e-be5a-071f38fb312e: Correct because one principle is that a portfolio's systematic risk accounts for most of its change in value over the long term. Also, beta captures an asset's systematic risk, or the portion of an asset's risk that cannot be eliminated by diversification. Therefore, beta typically accounts for most of the changes in portfolio value.
answerFeedback.41f90a26-a8a2-49b6-b243-7763832cbb14: Incorrect because alpha indicates whether the portfolio has outperformed the market. If alpha is positive, then the portfolio has outperformed the market; if alpha is negative, the portfolio has underperformed the market. Outperformance does not account for most of the changes in a portfolio's value over the long term but measures its value relative to a market.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Alt 16SXL 13U2
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a hedge fund:

Beginning-of-year assets under management (AUM) $100 million
End-of-year AUM before fees $120 million
Management fee, based on year-end AUM 2%
Incentive fee 20%
Hard hurdle rate 8%

If the incentive fee is calculated net of the management fee, the total fees earned by the fund manager are closest to:

answerFeedback.4a34ab46-e863-426a-ab68-82e76a1b4e6d:
Incorrect because a soft hurdle rate is used, not a hard hurdle rate.
Management fee = AUM end of year × 2% = $120,000,000 × 2% = $2,400,000;
Incentive fee ≠ ($120,000,000 − $100,000,000 – $2,400,000) × 20% = $3,520,000;
Total fees ≠ $2,400,000 + $3,520,000 = $5,920,000 ≈ $5.9 million.
answerFeedback.7bed87d1-78ea-488e-b488-81e7edf310ce:
Correct because the partnership agreement usually specifies that the performance fee is earned only after the fund achieves a return known as a hurdle rate. The hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return, typically 8%, that the GP must exceed in order to earn the performance fee. GPs typically receive 20% of the total profit of the private equity fund net of any hard hurdle rate, in which case the GP earns fees on annual returns in excess of the hurdle rate, or net of the soft hurdle rate, in which case the fee is calculated on the entire annual gross return as long as the set hurdle is exceeded.
Management fee = AUM end of year × 2% = $120,000,000 × 2% = $2,400,000;
Hard hurdle rate = $100,000,000 × 8% = $8,000,000;
Incentive fee = ($120,000,000 − $100,000,000 – $8,000,000 – $2,400,000) × 20% = $1,920,000;
Total fees = $2,400,000 + $1,920,000 = $4,320,000 ≈ $4.3 million.
answerFeedback.8e75aac2-a017-4d31-8fda-f268382eaf53:
Incorrect because the incentive fee is calculated on the gross return, not the net return.
Management fee = AUM end of year × 2% = $120,000,000 × 2% = $2,400,000;
Incentive fee ≠ ($120,000,000 − $100,000,000 – $8,000,000) × 20% = $2,400,000;
Total fees ≠ $2,400,000 + $2,400,000 = $4,800,000 = $4.8 million.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Moustra-15
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a bond:

Annual modified duration 7.534
Flat price (per 100 of par value) 92.084
Accrued interest (per 100 of par value) 1.458

The bond's money duration per 100 of par value is closest to:

answerFeedback.0befd23e-341e-4b56-a562-e5696600c851:
Incorrect because it uses flat price instead of full price.

MoneyDur = AnnModDur × (PVFlat + AI) ≠ AnnModDur × (PVFlat) = 7.534 × 92.084 ≈ 693.761 ≈ 694.
answerFeedback.48e7480c-9e2d-44a7-9ecc-d58d197fbb72:
Incorrect because it subtracts accrued interest instead of adding it. 

MoneyDur = AnnModDur × (PVFlat + AI) ≠ AnnModDur × (PVFlat – AI) = 7.534 × (92.084 – 1.458) = 7.534 × 90.626 ≈ 682.7763 ≈ 683.
answerFeedback.7b217f36-083f-4399-8a7d-d3c65d4ffa5e:
Correct because money duration (MoneyDur) is calculated as the annual modified duration (AnnModDur) times the full price (PVFull) of the bond including accrued interest.

MoneyDur = AnnModDur × PVFull. Using also the relation PVFull = PVFlat + AI, where PVFlat is the flat price and AI is the accrued interest, MoneyDur = AnnModDur × (PVFlat + AI) = 7.534 × (92.084 + 1.458) = 7.534 × 93.542 ≈ 704.745 ≈ 705.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09861
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about forward rates:

Time Period Forward Rate
0y1y 2.31%
1y1y 2.82%
2y1y 2.97%

The 2-year implied spot rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.52603a6e-15c3-43e9-9462-34832312afa3: Correct because the spot curve can be calculated as the geometric average of the forward rates. Here, the two-year implied spot rate is: (1.0231 × 1.0282) = (1 + z2)2, z2 = 0.0256 = 2.56%.
answerFeedback.86faf178-a675-46a3-8f81-ff912c3e7e11: Incorrect because the incorrect forward rates are used: (1.0282 × 1.0297) = (1 + z2)2, z2 = 0.0289 = 2.89%.
answerFeedback.882a9c26-b84c-49ea-b38a-dd3c3d63044d: Incorrect because this 2.82% is simply the one-year forward rate one year from now.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01036
entry.itemBody: A US Treasury security originally issued with five years to maturity is a Treasury:

answerFeedback.189c6d84-7d0e-4d72-be3d-cd629b975a8d: Correct because a Treasury security issued with a maturity longer than one year and up to 10 years is called a Treasury note.
answerFeedback.56dac6a9-5c5a-4c0b-a0ac-f7e6a0b20dab: Incorrect because a Treasury security issued with a maturity of greater than ten years is called a Treasury bond.
answerFeedback.de33effc-db5b-45e9-ad6b-c8d32025a90f: Incorrect because a Treasury security issued with a maturity of one year or less is called a Treasury bill.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516168
entry.itemBody: In behavioral finance, which of the following statements best describes the bias of conservatism? Investors:

answerFeedback.6d8c0089-a26c-40ea-b5dc-a18d10765d92: Incorrect because if investors assess new information and probabilities of outcomes based on similarity to the current state or to a familiar classification, then they show a behavioral bias called representativeness.
answerFeedback.c2c06ff0-c0a0-4f90-832a-4063c6911312: Correct because conservatism is a behavioral bias in which investors tend to be slow to react to new information and continue to maintain their prior views or forecasts.
answerFeedback.c39c1871-cffd-498b-8c91-5b824c5894d7: Incorrect because if investors focus on issues in isolation and respond to the issues based on how the issues are posed, then they show a behavioral bias called narrow framing.

choices.itemBody: A. assess new information and probabilities of outcomes based on similarity to the current state.
B. focus on issues in isolation and respond to the issues based on how the issues are posed.
C. tend to be slow to react to new information and continue to maintain their prior views or forecasts.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-24
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a bond:

Price Yield-to-Maturity (%)
103.52 3.7
103.84 3.3

If the bond currently trades at a price of 103.67 with a yield-to-maturity of 3.5%, the approximate convexity is closest to:

answerFeedback.8b34c8db-1ace-40f8-bb01-338344a2833e: Incorrect because approximate convexity is computed as: [(PV_) + (PV+) – (2 x PV0)]/[(ΔYield)2 x (PV0)]. This answer fails to square the change in yield in the denominator: [103.52 + 103.84 – (2 x 103.67)]/[0.002 x 103.67] = 0.09645 ≈ 0.096
answerFeedback.9a5f7e7f-4fa1-4d3a-893e-429d42e03b6a: Incorrect because approximate convexity is computed as: [(PV_) + (PV+) – (2 x PV0)]/[(ΔYield)2 x (PV0)]. This answer multiplies the change in yield in the denominator by 2 rather than squaring it: [103.52 + 103.84 – (2 x 103.67)]/[(2 x 0.002) x 103.67] = 0.0482 ≈ 0.048.
answerFeedback.f4273ba3-32b9-404e-818c-2d1906680deb: Correct because approximate convexity is computed as: [(PV_) + (PV+) – (2 x PV0)]/[(ΔYield)2 x (PV0)] = [103.52 + 103.84 – (2 x 103.67)]/[(0.002)2 x 103.67] = 48.22996 ≈ 48.230.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Huffman-08
entry.itemBody: Which of the following return measures is most appropriate when comparing the annual returns of an asset class over various long historical time periods?

answerFeedback.09a12014-58af-40fd-8f47-37fe76b55182: Correct because the geometric mean is a more accurate representation of returns for multiple holding periods over a long timespan than the arithmetic mean.
answerFeedback.729edd73-628b-488c-a279-af08beeb92b4: Incorrect because the geometric mean is a more accurate representation of returns for multiple holding periods over a long timespan than the arithmetic mean.
answerFeedback.f675478d-856d-44c3-8758-6ea80848cbaa: Incorrect because comparisons across various time periods are difficult and misleading using nominal returns. Therefore, it is more effective to rely on real returns than nominal returns when comparing the annual returns over long historical time periods.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Agarwal-09
entry.itemBody: If the forward price of a stock is equal to the current spot price, the price of an at-the-money put option applying put–call parity will be:

answerFeedback.0c651ee2-f401-4f03-b319-5134492facda: Incorrect because according to put-call parity  po – co = [X – Fo(T)]/(1+r)T If the forward price is equal to the spot price which is also the strike price as the options are at-the-money, the right hand side of the equation is zero and put price is equal to the call price and not lower than the call price.
answerFeedback.301e9c16-0d9c-44bc-b204-de456ee1892b: Incorrect because according to put-call parity  po – co = [X – Fo(T)]/(1+r)T If the forward price is equal to the spot price which is also the strike price as the options are at-the-money, the right hand side of the equation is zero and put price is equal to the call price and not higher than the call price.
answerFeedback.ba179519-d725-4b6e-8c99-0cdbf9586a13: Correct because according to put-call parity  po – co = [X – Fo(T)]/(1+r)T If the forward price is equal to the spot price which is also the strike price as the options are at-the-money, the right hand side of the equation is zero and put price is equal to the call price.

choices.itemBody: A. lower than the price of at-the-money call option.
B. equal to the price of at-the-money call option.
C. higher than the price of at-the-money call option.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Fairborn-11
entry.itemBody: Regarding hedge fund fee calculations, a high-water mark:

answerFeedback.b8c2df60-75bc-4f70-b755-719b148abdcc: Correct because in hedge funds, fee calculations also take into account a high-water mark, which reflects the highest value used to calculate an incentive fee. A high-water mark is the highest value of the fund investment ever achieved at a performance fee crystallization date, net of fees, by the individual LP. The use of high-water marks protects clients from paying twice for the same performance.
answerFeedback.c95a7020-edc4-4c63-ad4c-cc3f6a767b86: Incorrect because this distractor pertains to the clawback provision, not high water mark. A clawback provision reflects the right of LPs to reclaim part of the GP’s performance fee. Along either waterfall path, if a GP ever accrues (or actually pays itself) an incentive fee on gains that are not yet fully realized and then subsequently gives back these gains, an investor is typically able to claw back prior incentive fee accruals and payments.
answerFeedback.cb097448-2e03-49d9-a4ee-bd3ec9e1641d: Incorrect because the rate of the return that must be achieved before incentive fees are earned is the hurdle rate. The partnership agreement usually specifies that the performance fee is earned only after the fund achieves a return known as a hurdle rate. The hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return, typically 8%, that the GP must exceed in order to earn the performance fee.

choices.itemBody: A. represents the return on gains that are not yet fully realized.
B. protects the client from paying twice for the same performance.
C. is the rate of return that the general partner must exceed in order to earn a performance fee.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Chan-04
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three stocks that are the only constituents of an equal-weighted index:

  Beginning of the Year End of the Year
Stock Price per Share Shares Outstanding Price per Share Shares Outstanding
1 €30 500 €36 500
2 €50 200 €45 200
3 €40 300 €50 300

At the beginning of the year, the index value was 100. If it is not rebalanced during the year, the index value at the end of the year is closest to:

answerFeedback.0454fcfc-6c10-492e-874c-2c56df3a5761: Incorrect because 109.2 is the return for a price-weighted index. The sum of prices at the beginning of the period is (30 + 40 + 50) = 120. The sum of price at the end of the period is (36 + 45 + 50) = 131. Hence, the return is ((131/120) – 1) = 0.09166 ≈ 9.17%. Using this increase of 9.17%, the index value at year end is 100 × 1.0917 ≈ 109.2.
answerFeedback.ac447845-a734-44a5-ae41-605741614dee: Incorrect because 113.5 is the return for a value-weighted index. The market value at the beginning of the period is (30 × 500 + 50 × 200 + 40 × 300) = 37,000. The market value at the end of the period is (36 × 500 + 45 × 200 + 50 × 300) = 42,000. The return is ((42,000/37,000) –1) ≈ 0.1351 = 13.51%. Using this return, the index value at year end is 100 × 1.135 = 113.5.
answerFeedback.eb6b6b2f-9b4c-4307-8dd0-0a6d699d4fd2:
Correct because to calculate the index value of an equal-weighted index, the return for each security is first calculated using the formula: (ending value / beginning value) – 1.

Stock 1: ((36/30) –1) = 0.2 = 20%

Stock 2: ((45/50) –1) = –0.1 = –10%

Stock 3: ((50/40) –1) = 0.25 = 25%

These returns are then averaged: ((20% – 10% + 25%)/3) ≈ 11.67%.

The index value at year end is the beginning index value × average return =

100 × 1.1167 ≈ 111.7.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Lamba-01
entry.itemBody: The price of a futures contract will be higher than the price of a forward contract when the correlation between futures prices and interest rates is:

answerFeedback.3776b8ef-5ed5-4d6d-832e-1dc7bd39b324: Incorrect because if futures prices are positively correlated with interest rates, futures contracts are more desirable to holders of long positions than are forwards. This condition makes futures more attractive than forwards, and therefore their prices will be higher than forward prices. So, the price of a futures contract will be higher than the price of a forward contract when futures prices have a positive (not zero) correlation with interest rates.
answerFeedback.5199514b-a0b2-4c30-a8db-b182dddbf770: Correct because if futures prices are positively correlated with interest rates, futures contracts are more desirable to holders of long positions than are forwards. This condition makes futures more attractive than forwards, and therefore their prices will be higher than forward prices.
answerFeedback.64b99b60-3013-40cc-b88c-b7c32527ff82: Incorrect because if futures prices are positively correlated with interest rates, futures contracts are more desirable to holders of long positions than are forwards. This condition makes futures more attractive than forwards, and therefore their prices will be higher than forward prices. So, the price of a futures contract will be higher than the price of a forward contract when futures prices have a positive (not negative) correlation with interest rates.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Baillie-19
entry.itemBody: In the priority of claims, the class of corporate debt that has the lowest priority of payments in the event of default is most likely:

answerFeedback.3fdfaa5b-dca4-426a-882b-8cd17a032918: Correct because other lower-ranked debt includes subordinated debt and junior subordinated debt. Among the various creditor classes, these obligations have among the lowest priority of claims and frequently have little or no recovery in the event of default. Junior subordinated debt sits below subordinated debt in the priority of claims.
answerFeedback.736b642f-54a8-4163-97cf-515a7b173073: Incorrect because within secured debt, there is first mortgage and first lien debt, which are the highest ranked debt in terms of priority of repayment there can also be second lien, or even third lien, secured debt, which as the name implies, has a secured interest in the pledged assets. As secured debt ranks higher than unsecured debt, second lien debt is not the lowest priority payment in the priority of claims.
answerFeedback.9c6be860-f169-47e9-a3b5-8c9bfb32856a: Incorrect because other lower-ranked debt includes subordinated debt and junior subordinated debt. Among the various creditor classes, these obligations have among the lowest priority of claims and frequently have little or no recovery in the event of default. Junior subordinated debt sits below subordinated debt in the priority of claims and thus subordinated debt is not the lowest priority payment in the event of default.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 06SPH
entry.itemBody: The returns of Asset 1 and Asset 2 are perfectly positively correlated. If the assets have the same standard deviation of returns, the covariance between the returns of the assets is equal to the:

answerFeedback.017c45e6-27b6-45c7-aeeb-4ae1cf55b8b9: Incorrect because covariance can be expanded as Cov(R1,R2) = ρ12σ1σ2 where ρ12 is the correlation between returns. As the returns of the assets are perfectly positively correlated, the correlation is 1, and the covariance between the returns of the assets is the product of the standard deviations; ρ12σ1σ2 = 1 × σ1 × σ2. Since the standard deviations are the same (σ1 = σ2), the covariance is 1 × σ1 × σ1, which is the variance of Asset 1, rather than the product of the assets’ variances.
answerFeedback.2f560bd8-4777-4252-a0b9-b442874040fa: Incorrect because covariance can be expanded as Cov(R1,R2) = ρ12σ1σ2 where ρ12 is the correlation between returns. As the returns of the assets are perfectly positively correlated, the correlation is 1, and the covariance between the returns of the assets is the product of the standard deviations; ρ12σ1σ2 = 1 × σ1 × σ2. Since the standard deviations are the same (σ1 = σ2), the covariance is 1 × σ1 × σ1, which is the variance of Asset 1, rather than the standard deviation.
answerFeedback.e5b09466-eb5a-4edd-b4c6-6580cb8e1369: Correct because covariance can be expanded as Cov(R1,R2) = ρ12σ1σ2 where ρ12 is the correlation between returns.  As the returns of the assets are perfectly positively correlated, the correlation is 1, and the covariance between the returns of the assets is the product of the standard deviations; ρ12σ1σ2 = 1 × σ1 × σ2. Since the standard deviations are the same (σ1 = σ2), the covariance is 1 × σ1 × σ1, which is the variance of Asset 1.

choices.itemBody: C. variance of Asset 1’s returns times the variance of Asset 2’s returns.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.06-PM-Tomter-04
entry.itemBody: In contrast to life insurers, property and casualty insurers most likely:

answerFeedback.0a35ad09-0d1e-4d42-9ece-5a61fac01b01: Incorrect because it is a similarity of both types of insurers, not a key difference. To pay claims to policyholders, regulatory guidelines maintain that an insurance company's general account is typically invested conservatively in a diverse allocation of fixed-income securities.
answerFeedback.2e298a90-91bf-47e5-b2b3-5d216aa50e1a: Incorrect because it is a similarity of both types of insurers, not a key difference. In contrast to the general account, an insurer's surplus account is the difference between its assets and liabilities. An insurer’s surplus account typically targets a higher return than the general account and thus often invests in less-conservative asset classes, such as public and private equities, real estate, infrastructure, and hedge funds.
answerFeedback.4b11d514-8317-46d2-8dad-a596febb9006: Correct because a property and casualty insurer has a shorter time horizon and higher liquidity needs than a life insurer, and therefore invests in shorter-term securities. The unpredictable nature of property and casualty (P&C) claims forces P&C insurers to allocate a substantial proportion of their investments into liquid, short maturity assets. This need for liquidity also forces P&C companies to accept investments with relatively low expected returns. Liquidity is of less concern to life insurance companies given the greater predictability of life insurance payouts.

choices.itemBody: A. invest their general account assets in fixed-income securities.
B. accept investments with lower returns in their general account.
C. target a higher return in the surplus account than in the general account.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Kashyap-21
entry.itemBody: If the expected forward rate curve shifts downward after the inception of a swap, the mark-to-market value of the swap for the fixed-rate payer will most likely:

answerFeedback.9378c6b1-19fa-461e-9b91-6abf077acc99: Correct because a decline in expected forward rates immediately following trade inception will reduce the present value of floating payments, while the fixed swap rate will remain the same. Therefore, the value of the swap to the receiver of the floating payments (i.e., the fixed-rate payer) will decrease.
answerFeedback.c0f4193d-369f-43b8-b25e-fa6dd2ec808a: Incorrect because the opposite is true: A decline in expected forward rates immediately following trade inception will reduce the present value of floating payments, while the fixed swap rate will remain the same.
answerFeedback.eda01df7-ae7e-41e2-9b7b-510b81a251e2: Incorrect because a decline in expected forward rates immediately following trade inception will reduce the present value of floating payments, while the fixed swap rate will remain the same. The payments will remain the same but not the MTM value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-02
entry.itemBody: Short sellers most likely:

answerFeedback.3e08565e-3f0c-4128-9a46-c7a6d94a652d: Incorrect because security lenders will pay a short rebate rate to short sellers. Short sellers deposit collateral to security lenders, who invest the collateral in short-term securities, and rebate the interest to the short sellers at rates called short rebate rates.
answerFeedback.f792334f-8671-4a33-bdf4-751dd4922b81: Incorrect because short seller will deposit cash collateral to security lenders. To secure the security loans, lenders require that the short seller leave the proceeds of the short sale on deposit with them as cash collateral for the stock loan.
answerFeedback.fd111c56-b82d-46ba-b272-e4cc998c3cd0: Correct because the short sellers will pay the long sellers [security lenders] all dividends or interest that they otherwise would have received had they not lent their securities. These payments are called payments-in-lieu of dividends (or of interest).

choices.itemBody: A. pay a short rebate to security lenders.
B. receive cash collateral from security lenders.
C. make payments-in-lieu of dividends to security lenders.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-30
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in $ millions) about a hedge fund:

Initial investment cost 100
Profit, Year 1 25
Loss, Year 2 10

If the incentive fee is 20% and there is a clawback provision, the total incentive fee (in $ millions) for Years 1 and 2 is:

answerFeedback.3ff09e61-d649-4cdc-b2e2-ba5ba809b7e5: Correct because the GP would initially accrue a 20% of $25 million profit at the end of the first year, equal to $5 million. Typically, this amount would be held in escrow for the benefit of the GP but not actually paid. But then the GP loses $10 million of the initial $25 million gain, so the aggregate whole-of-fund gain at the end of the second year would be only $15 million; this amount times 20% would result in only an $3 million incentive fee. The general partner would then have to return $2 million of the previously accrued incentive fees to the capital accounts of LP investors because of the clawback provision.
answerFeedback.85389110-4b7f-4193-949d-86d175049a9c: Incorrect because it calculated the GP's incentive fee based on the profit/loss in Year 2 only. Therefore Total incentive fee = MAX [$0, –$10 million × 20%] = MAX [$0, –$2 million] = $0.
answerFeedback.f156a6d7-4e7f-4800-9a1a-2f47b8673328: Incorrect because it calculated the GP's incentive fee based on the profit/loss in Year 1 only. Therefore Total incentive fee = $25 million × 20% = $5 million.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-05
entry.itemBody: Statutory voting means that shareholders:

answerFeedback.294af349-5a72-471d-9e16-7338138be802: Correct because regular shareholder voting, where each share represents one vote, is referred to as statutory voting.
answerFeedback.541e59b7-165e-46e8-a5aa-7544fbf91475: Incorrect because regular shareholder voting, where each share represents one vote, is referred to as statutory voting. In contrast, the opportunity to vote by proxy allows a designated party—such as another shareholder, a shareholder representative, or management—to vote on the shareholders’ behalf.
answerFeedback.71ebb154-8e30-405a-a5d0-cfb3825f01b4: Incorrect because the key benefit to cumulative voting is that it allows shareholders with a small number of shares to apply all of their votes to one candidate, thus providing the opportunity for a higher level of representation on the board than would be allowed under statutory voting.

choices.itemBody: C. with a small number of shares are in a better position than in the case of cumulative voting.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Deriv 02DPQ
entry.itemBody: An investor purchases a European put option for $10 with a strike price of $95. If the price of the underlying at expiration is $80, the value of the option at expiration is equal to:

answerFeedback.8ab07837-ac06-4ddc-8128-c2e81a789a72: Incorrect because the value of a European put at expiration is the exercise value, which is the greater of zero or the exercise price minus the value of the underlying or pT = Max(0,X – ST). Where pT = exercise value, X is the exercise price and ST is the spot price at expiration. The value of the put option at expiration is not equal to Max(0,ST – X) or Max(0,$80 – $95) = $0.
answerFeedback.9d531536-9b0a-4e50-977d-9cd1341001ba: Incorrect because the value of a European put at expiration is the exercise value, which is the greater of zero or the exercise price minus the value of the underlying or pT = Max(0,X – ST). Where pT = exercise value, X is the exercise price and ST is the spot price at expiration. The value of the put option at expiration is not equal to the exercise value less the price paid for the put option or Max(0,$95 – $80) – p0 or $15 – $10 = $5 which represents the profit not the value of the option to the investor.
answerFeedback.be914742-f082-42ac-87fe-4868a9fca8b9: Correct because the value of a European put at expiration is the exercise value, which is the greater of zero or the exercise price minus the value of the underlying or pT = Max(0,X – ST). Where pT = exercise value, X is the exercise price and ST is the spot price at expiration. The value of the put option at expiration is = Max(0,$95 – $80) = $15.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Ng-22
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about direct ownership of real estate is most accurate?

answerFeedback.349c6d8f-c9be-47c0-8e92-9390dc283d7d: Correct because investing directly in real estate entails the need for specialized knowledge. The owners need to understand both general and local market characteristics, which requires local market knowledge.
answerFeedback.768d9fad-0bb2-4502-9ddd-30ef7976e169: Incorrect because control is a distinct advantage to owning real estate directly for property investors. Only the owner can decide when to buy or sell, when and how much to spend on capital projects, whom to select as tenants based on credit quality preference and tenant mix, and what types of lease terms to offer.
answerFeedback.ffa1680b-f921-4961-86e2-90087d403606: Incorrect because real estate owners can reduce their taxable income using non-cash property depreciation expenses and tax-deductible interest expenses.

choices.itemBody: A. Local real estate market expertise is important for success
B. Investors have no control over the tenant selection process
C. Investors cannot use non-cash property depreciation expenses to reduce taxable income

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Young-19
entry.itemBody: For which of the following industries are economic influences most important?

answerFeedback.2528d143-43a1-4f52-94bd-599ed4939375: Incorrect because economic influences are most important for cyclical sectors such as crude oil, natural gas, freight transportation, semiconductor, fintech, and digital advertising. Utilities is a defensive industry.
answerFeedback.80f97c41-b45d-45e6-8c84-1ab3f5b633a5: Incorrect because economic influences are most important for cyclical sectors such as crude oil, natural gas, freight transportation, semiconductor, fintech, and digital advertising. Pharmaceuticals is a defensive industry.
answerFeedback.8e67d490-33a0-40ce-bd67-c2e742234f39: Correct because economic influences are most important for cyclical sectors such as crude oil, natural gas, freight transportation, semiconductor, fintech, and digital advertising.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01997
entry.itemBody: If an investor wants to protect a short position from adverse price movements while also providing the opportunity for gains in the future, the investor should most likely use a:

answerFeedback.01602c62-6eec-4396-ac90-b6caefcdaa67: Incorrect because a limit buy order will be executed whenever the current market price is at or below the limit price specified. Therefore, it cannot protect a short position from adverse price movement. Rather, it specifies a profit target for the position.
answerFeedback.3da2ffc4-a5e9-454f-8780-ed30c8b22ff6: Correct because a stop order is an order in which a trader has specified a stop price condition. The stop order may not be filled until the stop price condition has been satisfied. Traders use them with the hope of stopping losses on positions that they have established. In the case of a short position, the investor places a stop buy order to protect paper gains. In the case of a short position, when the price rises above the stop price, the order becomes executable.
answerFeedback.7e439c49-0baa-4e90-acbd-93701856ebf0: Incorrect because a market order will be executed immediately and does not allow the investor any possibility for further gains.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Huffman-03
entry.itemBody: When making investment decisions, which of the following best describes a way to correct a behavioral bias caused by a cognitive error?

answerFeedback.844c893c-a03b-4f51-9a0f-699d859ab6ab: Correct because cognitive errors can often be corrected or eliminated through better information, education, and advice. Emotional biases, on the other hand, are harder to correct because they stem from impulses and intuitions.
answerFeedback.94705351-5bac-4d53-8923-36599d7387f5: Incorrect because this is a description of emotional biases rather than a correction for a behavioral bias.
answerFeedback.f7c20542-a8f0-4f79-b07c-c3f30a10fe80: Incorrect because this describes an emotional bias, loss aversion, rather than a correction for a behavioral bias.

choices.itemBody: B. Rely on intuition when making investments
C. Evaluate investments based on past gains and losses

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Deriv-Tyler-05
entry.itemBody: At maturity, the buyer of an over-the-counter (OTC) financial instrument faces the counterparty credit risk of the seller in:

answerFeedback.032053b4-9778-407c-9743-1b4e0fcc2fa1: Incorrect because although at maturity the buyer of a profitable long position in a forward faces the counterparty credit risk of the seller, the buyer of an in-the-money call option also faces this counterparty credit risk.
answerFeedback.80c2736d-b93e-4e22-9be7-5c16f59096e6: Incorrect because although at maturity the buyer of an in-the-money call option faces the counterparty credit risk of the seller, the buyer of a profitable long position in a forward also faces this counterparty credit risk.
answerFeedback.f3b694fb-bff7-4a08-9743-e91ae8be4f0c: Correct because at maturity the buyer of an in-the-money call option faces the counterparty credit risk of the seller, as does the buyer of a profitable long forward position.

choices.itemBody: A. a profitable long forward position only.
B. an in-the-money long call option position only.
C. both a profitable long forward position and an in-the-money long call option position.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516098
entry.itemBody:
The following is a trader’s order book for a stock:
Bid Volume Limit Price (CHF) Ask Volume
--- 42.76 6,800
--- 42.68 9,100
--- 42.64 6,600
--- 42.60 2,400
2,000 42.56 ---
4,000 42.52 ---
7,100 42.44 ---
5,000 42.42 ---
   
She receives an order to sell 9,000 shares with a limit price of CHF42.52. The average price (in CHF) at which the trades will be executed is closest to:

answerFeedback.01ad26f0-828d-4c26-92aa-10b41c15ae10:
Correct. Only 6,000 shares can be sold because the trader cannot execute below the $42.52 limit price. The average price is CHF42.53/share per the calculation below:

(2,000 shares * CHF42.56) + (4,000 shares * CHF42.52)/(2,000 + 4,000) = CHF42.53
answerFeedback.41d758f7-03d5-4835-be8e-fd40d73d6229:
Incorrect. This is the average price that would be generated if the order was a market order:

(2,000 shares * CHF42.56) + (4,000 shares * CHF42.52) + (3,000 shares*CHF42.44)/(2,000 + 4,000 + 3,000) = CHF42.50
answerFeedback.9f9fa28b-2b87-4bf0-8385-f1a0c04459ac: Incorrect. This is the limit price but is not the price at which the order is executed.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Fairborn-09
entry.itemBody: A US investor purchases an American depository receipt of a company based in Japan. If the total return of the company's stock in Japan is 3% and the Japanese yen appreciates by 3% against the US dollar, the investor's total return is closest to:

answerFeedback.86be7474-36b6-422a-94d9-dc4a70d9d422: Incorrect because the Japanese company returns 3% and the currency appreciates by 3% against the USD, so the total return is approximately 6%, not 3%.
answerFeedback.92346918-f574-4630-ba87-7d3a7f5828e3: Correct because for investors who purchase depository receipts, foreign exchange gains arise because of the change in the exchange rate between the investor’s currency and the currency that the foreign shares are denominated in. For example, US investors who purchase the ADRs of a Japanese company will earn an additional return if the yen appreciates relative to the US dollar. If the total return for a Japanese company was 10 percent in Japan and the yen depreciated by 10 percent against the US dollar, the total return of the ADR would be (approximately) 0 percent. If the yen had instead appreciated by 10 percent against the US dollar, the total return of the ADR would be (approximately) 20 percent. Because the Japanese company returns 3% and the currency appreciates by 3% against the USD, then the total return is approximately 6%.
answerFeedback.d1ba0ee3-13b0-47ed-8aa4-5312bb04a035: Incorrect because the Japanese company returns 3% and the currency appreciates by 3% against the USD, so the total return is approximately 6%, not 0%.
